channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Pryce guilty over Huhne points swap
item.description: Vicky Pryce, the former wife of ex-MP Chris Huhne, is found guilty of perverting the course of justice by taking speeding points on his behalf 10 years ago.

item.title: Man held after fatal bus stabbing
item.description: A man is arrested after a 16-year-old girl was stabbed to death on a rush-hour bus on one of Birmingham's busiest roads.

item.title: Processed meat 'early death' link
item.description: Sausages, ham, bacon and other processed meats appear to increase the risk of dying young, a study of half a million people across Europe suggests.

item.title: UN backs tough new N Korea sanctions
item.description: The UN Security Council unanimously approves fresh sanctions against North Korea in response to Pyongyang's nuclear test last month.

item.title: UK smoking 'halves' in 40 years
item.description: Smoking in Britain has more than halved and people are drinking on fewer nights of the week, according to a snapshot survey covering the past 40 years.

item.title: Ex-detective in Pistorius case quits
item.description: The ex-lead detective in the Oscar Pistorius case, who faces separate charges of attempted murder, has resigned, South African police say.

item.title: No alternative on economy, says PM
item.description: Changing course on the economy would plunge the UK "back into the abyss", the PM warns - after Vince Cable suggests spending may have to rise.

item.title: Sugar 'no intention' of paying out
item.description: Lord Sugar has "no intention" of paying out to Apprentice winner Stella English "unless instructed to do so", he tells a tribunal.

item.title: Berlusconi convicted over wiretap
item.description: Italy's former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi is convicted and sentenced to a year in jail over an illegal wiretap.

item.title: Graduate pay gap - women paid less
item.description: Female graduates are still likely to earn thousands of pounds less than men, according to a new report.

item.title: BoE rejects more economic stimulus
item.description: The Bank of England's rate-setting committee has kept interest rates at 0.5% and rejected calls to inject more stimulus into the economy.

item.title: Frozen phones give up data secrets
item.description: Putting an Android phone in a freezer for an hour can help get at its confidential contents, find German security researchers.

item.title: Jazz trumpeter Kenny Ball dies
item.description: Jazz trumpeter Kenny Ball has died at 82 after suffering from pneumonia, his manager confirms.

item.title: Bonnie Tyler chosen for Eurovision
item.description: Welsh pop singer Bonnie Tyler says she is "honoured" to be the UK's representative at the 2013 Eurovision Song Contest in Malmo, Sweden.

item.title: Lord Coe receives award at palace
item.description: London Olympic chief Lord Coe is made a member of the Order of the Companions of Honour at an investiture ceremony at Buckingham Palace.

item.title: RBS to compensate users over glitch
item.description: Royal Bank of Scotland says it will compensate RBS, NatWest and Ulster Bank customers who experienced disruption to their banking services.

item.title: John Lewis announces 17% staff bonus
item.description: Department store group John Lewis announces a 17% bonus for staff after reporting a rise in annual profits.

item.title: '13,000 EU migrants' report defended
item.description: The economist whose report led to expectations 13,000 people from new EU countries in 2004 would move to the UK, denies it was "spectacularly wrong".

item.title: End student visa loopholes - Labour
item.description: Student visa loopholes are allowing tens of thousands of people to enter the UK without any checks, shadow home secretary Yvette Cooper says.

item.title: Campaigners win child surgery case
item.description: A judge backs campaigners who claimed the consultation over changes to children's heart surgery in England and Wales was flawed.

item.title: Salt 'linked to immune rebellion'
item.description: The amount of salt in our diet could be driving our own immune systems to rebel against us leading to diseases such as multiple sclerosis, very early research suggests.

item.title: Call to name 'horsemeat supplier'
item.description: The government is urged to name a meat producer involved in supplying food containing horsemeat to schools and the armed forces.

item.title: School checks 'show improvement'
item.description: Almost half the schools inspected in England last term improved their overall rating, the chief inspector of schools Sir Michael Wilshaw has said.

item.title: Samsung loses Apple case in UK
item.description: South Korean phone-maker Samsung loses another patent fight against rival Apple, in the UK High Court.

item.title: Volvo unveils cyclist alert system
item.description: Volvo is to offer a product that can scan the road for cyclists and apply the brakes if it thinks a collision is imminent.

item.title: Canadian glaciers face 'big losses'
item.description: Canadian Arctic Archipelago glaciers could lose up to 20% of their volume if warming projections hold true, according to a new study.

item.title: Fun and games 'can save the planet'
item.description: A project will assess whether playing games can help increase people's interest in environmental issues, such as climate change.

item.title: Authors make libel reform plea
item.description: Writers including Sir Salman Rushdie and Stephen Fry sign a letter urging the UK's major political parties not to abandon libel reforms.

item.title: Artist Tracey Emin picks up CBE
item.description: Tracey Emin, once the wild child of the art world, receives her CBE from Princess Anne at Buckingham Palace.

item.title: Keep Calm and Please Stop
item.description: There was outrage when T-shirts went on sale with offensive variations of the Keep Calm and Carry On slogan. Is the joke over?

item.title: When Ian Fleming picked my grandfather
item.description: When Ian Fleming set up a secret commando unit during WWII, among those handpicked for duty was Theo Ionides - my grandfather.

item.title: London Welsh deducted five points
item.description: London Welsh are deducted five points and fined £15,000 for fielding ineligible player Tyson Keats.

item.title: Steaua Bucharest 1-0 Chelsea
item.description: Raul Rusescu's penalty gives Steaua Bucharest a first-leg lead over Chelsea in their Europa League last-16 tie.

item.title: England over-confident - Vaughan
item.description: Michael Vaughan accuses England of "disrespecting" cricket after being bowled out for 167 by New Zealand.

item.title: Tennis agrees new doping tests
item.description: Tennis will implement an Athlete Biological Passport programme to support the fight against drug cheats.

item.title: Suzi Perry on Vettel & Jordan's shirts
item.description: The BBC's F1 presenter Suzi Perry on her sporting idols, ideal dinner guests, Eddie Jordan's shirts and hopes for the new season

item.title: Fugitive TV baby death father jailed
item.description: A man wanted by police after his four-month-old son died when the child's mother knocked a television onto him at their home in Lancashire is jailed.

item.title: Boy struck by ambulance on 999 call
item.description: A boy is in a serious condition in hospital after being hit by an ambulance responding to an emergency call in Bath.

item.title: 450 miners warned of jobs threat
item.description: Scotland's coal mining industry is warning that the impact of cheap imports is putting jobs at risk.

item.title: Man killed mum and battered dad
item.description: A man admits killing his mother and battering his dad during a violent attack at their home in South Ayrshire.

item.title: Robinson stands by PSNI comments
item.description: The Northern Ireland first minister says he stands by comments that police must address a perception they treat loyalists differently than republicans.

item.title: Policing flag protests costs £20m
item.description: The cost of policing union flag protests in Northern Ireland has reached £20m.

item.title: 'Huge savings' from council mergers
item.description: Hundreds of millions of pounds could be saved if the existing six north Wales local authorities were replaced by just two, says a council leader.

item.title: Care abuse story 'must be told'
item.description: The full story of alleged neglect and fraud at care homes in south Wales "needs to be told", an MP says.

item.title: Kenya software bug hampered vote
item.description: Kenya's electoral commission says a computer bug is to blame for a large number of rejected votes in the presidential election, which has led to disputes and fraud claims.

item.title: Fifa queries Nigeria 'lesbian ban'
item.description: Fifa writes to the Nigerian Football Association about claims that lesbians are now banned from playing football there.

item.title: Malaysia rejects Filipino ceasefire
item.description: Malaysia rejects a call for a ceasefire in Sabah state to end an incursion by a group of Filipinos who say the land belongs to them.

item.title: UN observers seized in Syria 'safe'
item.description: UN observers taken hostage by Syrian rebels appear in videos saying they are safe and being well treated, amid reports of their expected release.

item.title: Bolshoi acid attack 'was a mistake'
item.description: A Bolshoi soloist accused over an attack on the ballet's artistic director tells a court he did not mean for acid to be used, but discussed beating him up.

item.title: French mother tried for 9/11 T-shirt
item.description: A French mother goes on trial for sending her son, named Jihad, to nursery school wearing a T-shirt reading "I am a bomb" and "Born on 11 September".

item.title: Body of Hugo Chavez lies in state
item.description: Tens of thousands of Venezuelans pay their last respects to the late President Hugo Chavez, who is lying in state before his funeral on Friday.

item.title: Slim tops Forbes rich list again
item.description: Mexican tycoon Carlos Slim again comes top of Forbes magazine's annual list of the world's richest billionaires, while Warren Buffett slips back.

item.title: Shot Palestinian dies in hospital
item.description: A Palestinian shot in the head by Israeli soldiers during a confrontation with stone-throwers has died of his wounds, hospital officials say.

item.title: Egypt election dates 'scrapped'
item.description: Egypt's electoral commission cancels dates for polls which were scheduled to begin next month, state TV reports.

item.title: Lion kills woman at California park
item.description: A lion kills a woman who was a volunteer intern at a private big cat park in California and is shot dead in the rescue attempt.

item.title: Arkansas adopts strict abortion ban
item.description: The state of Arkansas enacts the strictest anti-abortion law in the US, defying the governor's warning it would draw the state into litigation.

item.title: Day in pictures: 7 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 7 March

item.title: Hugo Chavez: A life in politics
item.description: Venezuela's President Chavez's life in politics

item.title: In pictures: Tweeting from space
item.description: A daily glimpse of life orbiting earth

item.title: Northern Ireland's changing murals
item.description: Sports stars replace paramilitaries

item.title: In pictures: Kenyan elections
item.description: Voting in the first elections since 2007

item.title: In pictures: Berlin Wall protest
item.description: Protests over plans to move surviving part of the Berlin Wall

item.title: Day in pictures: 6 March 2013
item.description: News photos over 24 hours: 6 March

item.title: In pictures: Pope's final audience
item.description: Pope Benedict XVI has held his final public audience

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: The government resists calls from Labour to name a firm that supplied beef containing horsemeat.

item.title: AUDIO: Tyler sings Eurovision song a cappella
item.description: Welsh pop singer Bonnie Tyler speaks to BBC World Service's Newshour about her Eurovision Song entry Believe in Me.

item.title: VIDEO: 'Monster' marlin landed by landlord
item.description: A pub landlord from Norfolk is celebrating after claiming to land a "monster" blue marlin fish with just a rod and a line.

item.title: VIDEO: New Pope's robes made in S, M and L
item.description: It has yet to be decided who the new Pope will be, but the robes that the next leader of the Catholic Church will wear have already been designed and made in Italy.

item.title: VIDEO: Rare baby rhino makes debut at zoo
item.description: A nine-day-old southern white rhino is the latest addition to the San Diego Zoo Safari Park.

item.title: VIDEO: Bolshoi acid attack 'was a mistake'
item.description: A Bolshoi Ballet dancer accused over an attack on artistic director Sergei Filin has told a court he did not mean for him to be splashed with acid.

item.title: VIDEO: Moon mining race under way
item.description: Google has offered a $20m grand prize to the first privately-funded company to land a robot on the moon and explore the surface.

item.title: VIDEO: Syrian refugees reach million mark
item.description: The number of Syrian refugees who have fled the conflict has reached a million, the UN has said.

item.title: VIDEO: Chinese rage at stolen baby murder
item.description: The case of a baby killed after the car in which he was sleeping was stolen has sparked outrage in China.

item.title: What if you could mine the Moon?
item.description: The pioneers with plans to mine the Moon

item.title: Falklanders prepare for referendum vote
item.description: Falkland islanders prepare for referendum on staying British

item.title: In pictures: Mammal photo winners
item.description: Mammal Photographer of the Year 2013 finalists announced

item.title: The man who demolished Shakespeare's house
item.description: The man who destroyed Shakespeare's house

item.title: Iraq 10 Years: Photographs by Sean Smith
item.description: How a war photographer captured life in Iraq

item.title: Actor puts stroke story on stage
item.description: The play about an actor not playing King Lear

item.title: The parent-child battles over a costume for World Book Day
item.description: The perils of dressing your child for World Book Day

item.title: Getting away from it all Hutterite-style
item.description: How North America's Hutterites get away from it all

item.title: Facebook gives itself a facelift
item.description: Facebook gives itself a facelift

item.title: Chavez and the era of anti-US bogeymen
item.description: Is the era of the 'anti-American' bogeyman at an end?

item.title: Budget 'sacred cows under threat in welfare row
item.description: Sacred cows under threat in welfare budget row, says Allegra Stratton

item.title: Economy: TINA is back
item.description: Nick Robinson explains why Mrs Thatcher's phrase is back

item.title: Vince Cable's plan B: a "matter of judgment"
item.description: Stephanie Flanders says Cable's plan B is a 'matter of judgment'

item.title: Google Street View - a closer look
item.description: The Street View cars have been roaming Britain again

item.title: Why do the Italians live longer than us?
item.description: Why do the Italians live longer than us? - Fergus Walsh asks
